column1: Thomas Edison made early phonographs in the 1870s. He originally used tin foil to record the sound. Soon wax cylinders were used in place of the tin foil. The cylinders could be taken off the machine and put back on without destroying the recording. Although discs were made as early as 1888
column2: it was not until 1902 that discs became more popular than cylinder records. Discs were first made of a shellac mixture
column4: often abbreviated as "vinyl". Singles usually carried only one or two songs or recordings. EPs (extended play records) carried from three to five songs. Albums carried many more recordings; a dozen was normal
column5: or from 30 to 45 minutes of playing time. These formats are still used today
column7: and playing time for singles and albums has grown considerably.Vinyl records lost popularity but never went out of production. Now
column8: in recent years vinyl is gaining popularity
column9: while CD record shops have gone out of business
column10: more and more vinyl only record shops are opening. Many argue the higher sound quality of vinyl compared to newer formats.
